0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-accusers-factbox-idUSKCN12D31N	Factbox: Women who have alleged inappropriate conduct by Trump	"
Several women have accused U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump of sexual advances and groping. Among his accusers are a Miss Utah beauty pageant winner
column2: a businesswoman
column3: a reporter and a receptionist. He has denied the accusations.In a 2005 video that emerged on Oct. 7
column4: Trump boasted about grabbing women by the genitals and kissing them without their consent. In a U.S. presidential debate on Oct. 9
column5: he said he was embarrassed by what he called locker-room talk but had not engaged in the conduct he described in the video. Trump has called ""absolutely false"" allegations by several women of groping and other misconduct
column6: reported by The New York Times and other media. He has called the women ""sick
column7: and at Wednesday night's final presidential debate
column8: he alleged that the women were either controlled by Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton's campaign or seeking ""their 10 minutes of fame."" Following are some of the allegations against Trump: Jill Harth Houraney
column9: a former Trump beauty pageant business associate
column10: filed a $125 million lawsuit in 1997 against Trump alleging that on Jan. 24
column14: Trump ""forcibly removed plaintiff to a bedroom
column15: whereupon defendant subjected plaintiff to defendant's unwanted sexual advances."" A Trump representative was quoted on Oct. 7 in The New York Times as saying
column16: ""Mr. Trump denies each and every statement made by Ms. Harth."" The lawsuit was dropped in May 1997.Temple Taggart McDowell
column18: was quoted by The New York Times in a report published on May 15 as saying that Trump ""kissed me directly on the lips"" when the two were introduced in 1997
column19: when she was 21. Taggart told the Times
column22: gross.'"" The Times story said Trump disputed the report and added that Trump said ""he is reluctant to kiss strangers on the lips.""

column3: recounted in an video interview posted on The New York Times website on Oct. 12 that Trump grabbed her breasts and tried to put his hand up her skirt on a flight to New York in or around 1980 when she was a 38-year-old traveling businesswoman. In a tweet and in a later speech on Oct. 13

column5: formerly a receptionist at a real estate firm
column6: told The New York Times in a report published on Oct. 12   that Trump ""kissed me directly on the mouth"" in 2005 at Trump Tower in Manhattan when she was 22. In a tweet and in a later speech on Oct. 13
column7: Trump called the Times story a total fabrication.

column1: Natasha Stoynoff
column2: a reporter
column3: wrote a first-person account that described Trump kissing her without her consent in December 2005 at Trump's Florida home
column4: Mar-a-Lago
column5: while she was working on an article about him and his third wife
column6: Melania
column7: for People magazine. In the account published by People on Oct. 12

column1: Summer Zervos
column2: who was a contestant on Trump's reality TV show ""The Apprentice"" in 2006
column3: said at a news conference on Oct. 14 in Las Vegas that Trump tried to get her to lie down on a bed with him when she met him in 2007 to discuss a possible job. Zervos said she complied with a request to sit next to Trump
column4: and
column5: ""He then grabbed my shoulder and began kissing me very aggressively and placed his hand on my breast."" Trump at a rally in North Carolina this month denounced the allegations made by a series of women
column6: calling them fabrications.Kristin Anderson
column7: in a video posted on the website of The Washington Post on Oct. 14
column8: said Trump put his hand up her skirt in a crowded New York nightclub in the early 1990s in an unwanted advance
column9: when she had never even met him. ""He did touch my vagina through my underwear
column11: Anderson said in the video interview. Trump's campaign did not respond to requests for comments on the allegations at the time they were made public.  Yoga instructor Karena Virginia
column12: at a news conference in New York City on Thursday
column13: said Trump approached her outside the U.S. Open tennis tournament in 1998. They had never met
column15: she said. She alleged that Trump commented on her legs and then touched her breast before she was able to get into a car and be driven away. Trump campaign spokeswoman Jessica Ditto said the accusation was a publicity-seeking attack coordinated with Clinton
column16: and added: ""Voters are tired of these circus-like antics and reject these fictional stories."" (Reporting by Mike Stone in Washington
column17: Steve Holland and Dan whitcomb in North Carolina
column18: and David Ingram in New York; Editing by Leslie Adler and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN12D128	'Absolutely false
column2: ' Trump says defiantly after women's groping allegations	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| WEST PALM BEACH
column2: Fla.

column1: WEST PALM BEACH
column2: Fla. Donald Trump assailed as ""absolutely false"" the allegations by several women that he groped them
column3: and accused Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column4: the media and lobbyists of engaging in an effort to stop him from winning the White House.With his numbers dropping in opinion polls ahead of the Nov. 8 election
column5: the Republican U.S. presidential nominee told supporters at a rally in Florida that his campaign was engaged in ""a struggle for the survival of our nation.""Trump said accusations that he groped women in a series of incidents going back to the 1980s were part of a coordinated attempt to keep him from the Oval Office.    ""These vicious claims about me of inappropriate conduct with women are totally and absolutely false
column6: he said
column7: adding that ""the Clintons know it."" He said he would make public at some point evidence to dispute the charges.""I've never met these people. I don't even know who they are. They're made-up stories
column8: Trump said later on Thursday during a speech in Ohio. Trump spoke after The New York Times reported that two women said they had endured sexual aggression from him
column9: and several other women made similar allegations in other media outlets.The New York businessman's campaign was already struggling to contain a crisis after a video surfaced last week showing him bragging in 2005 about groping women and making unwanted sexual advances.First lady Michelle Obama criticized Trump in scathing terms in a campaign speech for Clinton in New Hampshire on Thursday.Her voice close to cracking with emotion
column11: ""This was a powerful individual speaking freely and openly about sexually predatory behavior
column12: and actually bragging about kissing and groping women
column13: using language so obscene that many of us were worried about our children hearing it when we turn on the TV.""""It's one of countless examples of how he has treated women his whole life
column14: she added. ""... The shameful comments about our bodies
column15: the disrespect of our ambitions and intellect
column16: the belief that you can do anything you want to a woman -- it is cruel.""One woman
column18: appeared on camera on The New York Times website to recount how Trump grabbed her breasts and tried to put his hand up her skirt on a flight from the Midwest to New York in or around 1980. (nyti.ms/2dx8k5R)Leeds told CNN on Thursday that Trump also kissed her face in an incident that lasted about 15 minutes. ""That's long enough
column21: described how Trump ""kissed me directly on the mouth"" in an unwanted advance in 2005 at Trump Tower in Manhattan
column22: where she was a receptionist at a real estate firm.

column1: Reuters could not independently verify the incidents. Leeds and Crooks did not respond to requests for comment from Reuters.The New York Times said on Thursday it stood by its story and rejected charges the article was libelous after a lawyer for Trump threatened legal action and demanded a retraction.        SLUMP IN POLLS

Trump has slumped in opinion polls in recent days as the uproar over the video threatened to engulf his White House campaign in a way that his earlier controversies had not.A Reuters/Ipsos survey showed one in five Republicans thought Trump's comments about groping women disqualified him from the presidency. The poll showed him 8 percentage points behind Clinton among likely voters. Trump trailed Clinton by up to 11 percentage points in other polls.
Establishment Republicans have struggled to get behind Trump
column2: alarmed by both his style and some of his policy proposals.Within hours of The New York Times report
column3: several other media outlets published similar reports. People magazine published a detailed first-person account from one of its reporters
column4: Natasha Stoynoff. (bit.ly/2dTm90D)Stoynoff said Trump pinned her against a wall at his Florida estate in 2005 and kissed her as she struggled to get away. ""I turned around
column5: and within seconds
column6: he was pushing me against the wall
column7: and forcing his tongue down my throat
column10: denied the People story in a Twitter message and in his speech in Florida on Thursday
column11: and mocked the writer.""I ask her a simple question. Why wasn't it part of the story that appeared 12 years ago? Why didn't they make it part of the story ... if she had added that
column12: it would have been the headline.""

column1: Look at her and look at her words
column2: he said. ""You tell me what you think. I don't think so.""Trump's wife
column3: Melania
column4: on Thursday posted on Twitter a letter from her attorney to People that said details in the story were false
column5: pointing to Stoynoff's recollection in the piece that she later ran into Melania Trump and spoke to her in New York City. The attorney
column6: Charles Harder
column7: said in the letter that Stoynoff and Melania Trump ""were never friends or even friendly"" and demanded that People ""print a prominent retraction and apology.""The Palm Beach Post reported an allegation by Mindy McGillivray
column10: that Trump had grabbed her bottom 13 years ago while she was working at his Mar-a-Lago estate as a photographer's assistant.""There is no truth to this whatsoever
column13: told the Post.McGillivray could not be reached for comment.At the Florida rally on Thursday
column14: Trump said he had been prepared for attacks
column15: but ""I never knew it would be this vile
column16: that it would be this bad
column17: that it would be this vicious."" He said the ""corrupt political establishment"" was trying to stop him so it could carry out a program of ""radical globalization and the disenfranchisement of working people.""    ""Our great civilization
column18: here in America and across the civilized world has come upon a moment of reckoning
column22: and trying to seduce a married woman. He said during a presidential debate on Sunday that he had not actually done the things he had boasted about
column24: which he called private ""locker room talk.""The Washington Post endorsed Clinton on Thursday. ""In the gloom and ugliness of this political season
column25: one encouraging truth is often overlooked: There is a well-qualified
column26: well-prepared candidate on the ballot ... we endorse her without hesitation
column27: it said. (Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton
column36: Doina Chiacu; Writing by Alistair Bell and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-comstock-idUSKCN12K1A7	Congressional race in Virginia shows Trump drag on Republicans	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Barbara Comstock is trying to untether herself from Donald Trump in her re-election bid for the U.S. Congress
column2: but the Virginia Republican's struggles show how difficult that can be.Comstock represents a wealthy House of Representatives district in northern Virginia where Trump has become a burden
column3: one that her opponent is wrapping around Comstock's neck.In local campaign ads
column4: Democratic challenger LuAnn Bennett takes every opportunity to tie Comstock to the New York real estate developer and Republican presidential nominee.The strategy may be working. The Cook Political Report
column5: a non-partisan election tipsheet
column6: moved the Comstock-Bennett race from ""lean Republican"" to ""toss up"" on Wednesday
column7: citing Trump's unpopularity in much of the district.This is despite Comstock's months-long effort to jettison Trump. In April
column8: the former lobbyist and state legislator said Trump was actually a Democrat who knows ""nothing"" about the economy.She said in December that his plan to ban Muslim immigrants was ""un-American"" and ""a silly idea."" In March
column9: she gave campaign donations she got from Trump to charity.Earlier this month
column10: she said Trump's boasts about groping women
column12: were ""vile."" She said she would not vote for him and urged Trump to drop out of the race against Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.But it may be too late to undo the damage
column14: with just 19 days remaining until Election Day.

column1: In a normal year
column2: Comstock would be a clear favorite
column3: but right now her front runner status is in question because of Trump
column4: said Kyle Kondik
column5: managing editor of Sabato's Crystal Ball at the Virginia Center for Politics.    ""He (Trump) was a gift"" to her campaign
column6: said Bennett
column7: a 63-year-old real estate executive.Bennett said Comstock
column9: waited too late in her re-election campaign to announce she would not vote for Trump
column10: and argued that Comstock's views on immigration
column11: abortion and climate change are ""shockingly similar"" to Trump's.Asked on Wednesday about voters' view of her repudiation of Trump
column14: would be a ""rubber stamp"" for Clinton.

column1: I'm the only one of the two of us who ... has a record of speaking out against people
column2: whether it's in my own party or not
column3: Comstock
column4: a Georgetown University-educated lawyer
column5: told reporters after a debate with Bennett.""I've made clear that I'm going to be my own woman.""Stretching from suburban Washington to the Shenandoah valley and the West Virginia border
column6: Comstock's district is home to thousands of government workers
column7: as well as many well-heeled lobbyists and what Trump might call the Washington ""elites."" The area has been represented by a Republican in Congress since 1981
column8: but has been a swing district in presidential years.

column1: Bennett said Democrats expect about 140
column2: 000 more voters to turn out in the district in this presidential election year than when Comstock was elected in a mid-term election two years ago.""We have a growing Latino community
column3: we have a growing Asian community
column4: and those communities are very unsettled by the rhetoric they've heard on the Republican side of the fence
column5: and really worried about where this country is going
column6: she said.Kondik said
column7: ""This is one of the most highly educated districts in the country
column8: and it's filled with the kinds of Republicans that Trump could very well turn off.""A recent poll by the Wason Center for Public Policy in Newport News
column10: showed Clinton leading Trump by 55 percent to 21 percent in northern Virginia.That suggests that for Comstock to win
column11: some Clinton backers will need to ""split"" their tickets to vote for Comstock
column12: who made a name for herself in the 1990s as a congressional staffer dedicated to investigating members of the Clinton administration.Stephen Farnsworth
column13: professor of political science and international affairs at the University of Mary Washington in Fredericksburg
column16: Trump went from being a drag on the Comstock campaign to an anchor."" (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Alistair Bell)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN12K27Q	Trump says he'll accept 'clear' election result
column2: reserves right to challenge	"

column1: DELAWARE
column2: OHIO Republican Donald Trump on Thursday said he would accept a ""clear"" election result but reserved the right to file a legal challenge
column3: clarifying his stance a day after he refused to promise he would trust the outcome if he loses on Nov. 8.""Of course
column4: I would accept a clear election result
column5: but I would also reserve my right to contest or file a legal challenge in the case of a questionable result
column6: Trump said at a rally in Ohio. Asked on Wednesday at his final debate with Democrat Hillary Clinton if he would accept a losing outcome
column7: Trump said he would ""keep you in suspense.""

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-turkey-carter-idUSKCN12K21H	U.S. partnership with Turkey in Islamic State fight 'very strong'	"
WASHINGTON The U.S. partnership with Turkey in countering Islamic State is ""very strong
column2: U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said at a news conference on Thursday.""With respect to Turkey
column3: our partnership is very strong in the counter-ISIL campaign
column4: Carter said

column1: Carter made the comments after Turkish air strikes pounded a group of Kurdish fighters allied to a U.S.-backed militia in northern Syria overnight

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-socialmedia-idUSKCN12K0I4	Trump's 'bad hombres' and 'nasty woman' remarks stoke online outrage	"
By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump stirred social media ire on Wednesday after he said: ""We have some bad hombres here"" and referred to Democratic rival Hillary Clinton as ""such a nasty woman.""The remarks during the third and final presidential debate came as Trump struggles to attract support from Latinos and women ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.During the face-off in Las Vegas
column2: Trump repeated his call for tougher security at the Mexican border
column3: saying: ""We have to keep the drugs out of our country."" Adding he would also go after major drug dealers in the United States
column4: he said: ""We have some bad hombres here and we're going to get them out.""Social media users quickly seized on the remark.""This #BadHombres is the first of his family to graduate from college
column5: did Americorps & taught in public schools
column6: tweeted Jose N Miranda.""Sometimes I forget this is a presidential debate and not an SNL (Saturday Night Live) skit #badhombres
column7: wrote Twitter user Ian Mayberry.The term ""Bad Hombres"" became one of the most-discussed topics of the night on U.S. social media and was tweeted out about 134
column8: 000 times during and immediately after the debate
column9: according to digital marketing technology company Amobee.

column1: Trump has aroused criticism for inflammatory comments about Mexican illegal immigrants during his presidential bid. During a speech to kick off his campaign in June 2015
column2: Trump accused Mexico of sending rapists and other criminals to the United States.In late August
column3: Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto met with the Republican nominee and said later that Trump's policies ""could represent a huge threat to Mexico.""'SUCH A NASTY WOMAN'

column1: Later in the debate
column2: Trump interjected as Clinton said she would raise taxes on the wealthy to help fund the U.S. government's Social Security retirement program and that Trump would be paying higher taxes too unless he could get out of it.""Such a nasty woman
column3: he said. The comment struck many online as sexist
column4: with over 300
column5: 000 tweeting the phrase ""nasty woman"" by the early hours of Thursday.

column1: Calling someone a 'nasty woman' on live television is so deeply and unbelievably offensive
column2: tweeted Danielle Suchet. ""'What a nasty woman.' That was the viscerally
column3: awful
column4: genuine part
column5: wrote Jake Swanton.Trump's campaign was shaken by the recent release of a 2005 tape in which he boasted of kissing and touching women without their consent. Several women have since charged that he groped them
column6: allegations he has described as ""absolutely false.""(This version of the story has been refiled to clarify Amobee company role) (Reporting by Amy Tennery; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-asia-idUSKCN12K0IW	Women in Asia-Pacific express dismay over U.S. presidential campaign	"
By Ami Miyazaki and J.R. Wu
| TOKYO/TAIPEI
TOKYO/TAIPEI Women in the Asia-Pacific region expressed dismay on Thursday about the U.S. presidential campaign's focus on the emotional topic of sexual harassment
column2: saying it shows both democracy and the rights of women in America have some way to go.In a fiery final debate on Wednesday night in Las Vegas
column3: Republican nominee Donald Trump accused Democrat rival Hillary Clinton's campaign of orchestrating a series of accusations by women who said the businessman had made unwanted sexual advances. Clinton
column4: who would be America's first female president
column5: said the women came forward after Trump said he had never made unwanted advances on women. His denial came after a 2005 video surfaced earlier this month in which he was recorded bragging about groping women against their will.Hsiao Bi-khim
column6: a lawmaker from Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party
column7: said she found it ""rather incredible"" Trump had survived politically in the face of the allegations.If a candidate in Taiwan was caught on tape making similar remarks
column8: ""I don't think such a person would survive a presidential campaign
column9: she said.Taiwan in January elected its first woman president
column11: and on gender equality at least
column12: appears more advanced politically than the United States
column13: she said.""Not only have we elected a woman president
column14: but we have a higher percentage of women who are independently involved in politics and in leadership positions

column1: Japan's former minister for gender equality
column2: Kuniko Inoguchi
column3: said the rest of the world has been dismayed to see the U.S. campaign devolve into ""a downgraded debate on women's issues"" and it wouldn't be happening if Clinton were a man running for president.""So when the glass ceiling breaks
column4: there are a lot of injuries that a woman must bear
column5: Inoguchi said.Mari Miura
column6: a Sophia University political science professor specializing in women's issues
column7: said Japanese politicians have also sparked outrage for comments demeaning women in the past.

column1: We hear such comments constantly from Japanese conservative men
column2: she said. ""There are so many incidents that people get used to it and it's easier to let it go.""A study commissioned by Japan's Ministry of Health
column3: Labour and Welfare
column4: published in March
column5: found 28.7 percent of women had experienced some form of sexual harassment
column6: and 40 percent of those said they had experienced unwanted touching.'TRAGEDY FOR WOMEN EVERYWHERE'

column1: South Korea
column2: which in 2012 elected its first woman president
column3: Park Geun-hye
column4: has slowly become more accepting of women politicians
column5: said Park Young-sun
column6: a female senior member of the Democratic Party of Korea
column7: which has a majority in parliament.Park Young-sun said that when she first entered parliament
column9: female lawmakers were considered ""decorative items on display"".

column1: They were given positions within the parties like flowers being placed decoratively here and there. Now it's better."" Nurul Izzah
column2: a Malaysian member of parliament and daughter of jailed opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim
column3: said the U.S. campaign debate was ""a tragedy for women everywhere"".Nurul said ""there is a lot of condescension
column4: prejudice"" in Malaysian politics
column5: but ""political attacks are not really focused on gender-specific issues"".A senior female member of Indonesian President Joko Widodo's government said what Trump has been accused of doing with women ""would make him definitely unelectable in Indonesia"".""What shocks me is that many Americans still accept him and make excuses for him.""She said sexual assault is not part of Indonesia's political culture
column6: ""and even if there are instances
column7: it is not tolerated
column8: and it doesn't sit well with either men or women"".

column1: 'EVE-TEASING'
India
column2: where sexual harassment and groping on public transport is known as ""Eve-teasing""
column3: went through its own soul-searching over the issue after the death of a young woman who was gang-raped on a moving bus in New Delhi in 2012.""In our climate
column4: a Donald Trump-like figure would have to apologize publicly
column5: said Maya Mirchandani
column6: foreign affairs editor at NDTV
column7: a leading news channel.When she started in TV news in the 1990s
column8: young female reporters were called ""soundbite soldiers""
column9: she said. ""Print journalists alleged that we used our bodies to stop politicians and get them to talk to us.""Today
column10: Indian law sets clear guidelines for companies to ensure harassment in the workplace is dealt with
column12: known for its colorful language and no-holds barred political culture
column13: has been shocked by the U.S. presidential campaign
column15: female president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.The closest Australia has come to anything similar recently was a 'ditch the witch' campaign adopted by supporters of the conservative opposition against former prime minister Julia Gillard
column17: when she argued for a carbon tax during her time in power from 2010 to 2013.""Personally
column18: I think Donald Trump would definitely be unelectable in Australia
column19: Kearney said. ""I don't think there is any place in Australia for that level of misogyny and cheapening of politics."" (Additional reporting by Christine Kim in Seoul
column21: Swati Pandey and Jane Wardel in Sydney
column23: Joseph Sipalan in Kuala Lumpur and Douglas Busvine In New Delhi; Writing by Bill Tarrant; Editing by Will Waterman)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-russia-idUSKCN12K0E7	Clinton accuses Trump of being Putin's 'puppet'	"
By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democrat Hillary Clinton accused Republican presidential rival Donald Trump on Wednesday of being a ""puppet"" for Russian President Vladimir Putin
column2: whose country has been accused by U.S. intelligence officials of meddling in the U.S. election.Putin has been repeatedly thrust into the campaign for the Nov. 8 U.S. election. Trump has praised him as a stronger leader than U.S. President Barack Obama
column3: drawing criticism from Clinton and some Republicans that he is too cozy with the Russian president. Trump has also refused to concede that Russia was behind the hacking of Democratic Party emails.During Wednesday's presidential debate
column4: Trump said he did not know Putin but would likely get along better with the Russian leader than Clinton
column5: a former secretary of state.""He said nice things about me
column6: Trump said. ""He has no respect for her
column7: he has no respect for our president and I'll tell you what
column8: we're in very serious trouble.""Clinton responded: ""Well that's because he'd rather have a puppet as president of the United States.""

column1: No
column2: you're the puppet
column3: Trump retorted
column4: adding Clinton disliked Putin because he ""has outsmarted her at every step of the way."" Earlier this week
column5: Trump suggested that if elected
column6: his first meeting with a foreign leader would be with Putin.

column1: U.S.-Russian relations have deteriorated in recent years over Moscow's intervention in the Syrian conflict
column2: its annexation of the Crimean region from Ukraine and concerns about cyber attacks.Director of National Intelligence James Clapper
column3: who oversees 17 U.S. intelligence agencies
column4: has suggested that recent computer hacks targeting the Democratic Party were perpetrated by Russians
column5: and predicted that cyber attacks would be a pressing challenge for the next president.Putin said on Sunday that Russia did not seek confrontation with the United States and was not trying to influence the U.S. election.

column1: (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-election-ohio-idUSKCN12K04J	Voters illegally removed from Ohio rolls may cast provisional ballots: judge	"

A federal judge in Ohio laid out a plan on Wednesday for the state to restore voting privileges for people who were illegally removed from the state's voter rolls over the past five years.The ruling stems from a case in which the ACLU and other plaintiffs sued
column2: saying Ohio's process for removing people who had died or moved away from voter rolls was illegal because it purged people simply for not voting and not responding to a letter from the state.Voting rights cases have become pivotal battlegrounds ahead of the Nov. 8 election between Democrat Hillary Clinton and  Republican Donald Trump.The American Civil Liberties Union and others have challenged laws in Wisconsin
column3: Michigan and North Carolina over voting rights issues.In the Ohio case
column4: the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati said Ohio's process for removing inactive voters was illegal
column5: reversing an earlier ruling by U.S. District Judge George C. Smith.

column1: In response
column2: Smith on Wednesday ordered the state to allow people who had been removed from the rolls to cast provisional ballots on election day.Those ballots will be checked against voter rolls
column3: and if people were purged in the years 2011
column5: their votes will be counted and their registration restored.

column1: They'll have to put a provisional ballot which will take a little more time but if they do that
column2: that vote will count
column3: said Stuart Naifeh
column4: an attorney with Demos
column5: a voter rights and income inequality advocacy group that was among those suing over the policy.Joshua Eck
column6: a spokesman for Ohio Secretary of State Jon Husted
column7: said the solution was a workable one because it did not require the wholesale restoration of voting privileges to people who had moved away
column8: died or otherwise become ineligible to vote.

column1: (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein in Sacramento
column2: Calif.; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-taco-idUSKCN12J2U4	Before debate
column2: protesters build 'wall of taco trucks' outside Trump hotel	"

column1: By Jane Ross
LAS VEGAS - As Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump prepared to go head-to-head with Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in their third and final debate in Las Vegas on Wednesday
column2: hundreds of hospitality workers and protesters gathered outside the hotel Trump co-owns near the Las Vegas Strip. Demonstrators waved signs and banners next to what organizers called a ""wall"" of taco trucks. That was a reference to Trump's proposal to build a wall on the U.S. border with Mexico
column3: as well as a riff on comments by Trump supporter Marco Gutierrez who said that without action on immigration reform
column4: ""You're going to have taco trucks on every corner.""""We have fought for our rights and we don't want Donald Trump to take them away from us
column5: said Las Vegas resident Miguel Faria. ""If this man gets the presidency then everything will be ruined."" Several protesters wore sashes printed with the phrases ""Miss Piggy"" and ""Miss Housekeeping
column6: using the names that Clinton has said Trump called a former beauty queen who had gained weight and who was Latina.The protest was organized by the Culinary Union
column7: which represents about 57
column9: the majority of whom are Latino.

column1: Luis Hernandez
column2: a musician with the norteno band ""Los Tigres del Norte
column3: encouraged Latino voters to head to the polls on Nov. 8. ""We can't just go on hoping someone will vote on our behalf
column4: he told Reuters. ""We need to go out and vote because the Hispanic vote is going to make the difference in these elections.""

column1: Among the speakers at the protest was civil rights leader the Rev. Jesse Jackson
